YOUR LIFE IN FOOD BEGINS HERE

You love food. And you’re pretty sure you want to make it your life. If this sounds like you, then The Culinary Institute of America is the only place you need to be. Only at the CIA will you get the immersive learning and industry connections that will prepare you to lead in the kitchen, the boardroom, or anywhere else you want to go in food.

At our heart, we develop and nurture a chef’s mindset in every CIA student and graduate—fulfilled, influential professionals who understand the importance of taste in leading sustainable change in the food world.
Put your focus on your CIA education, thanks to generous scholarships and aid that help make college more affordable.
Take a résumé-building internship, where expert mentors will help prepare you for your future in food and hospitality.
Join our alumni network of 50,000  food changemakers and industry leaders ready to hire fellow CIA grads.
Come feel the energy and excitement of our food-centric community. Join us for an open house or daily tour.
So many career paths in food! Not sure what yours is yet? No worries.
College is all about exploring, and we’ll help you discover what’s right for you.
They’re at the foundation of all you’ll do here.
Go deeper in the food world, with
culinary science, applied food studies, hospitality management,
Further advance your learning—and your career—with our master’s degree programs in

The newest degree to propel you to new heights in the exciting world of Hospitality—we’re not just talking restaurants, but hotels and resorts, theme parks, bars and nightclubs, cruise lines.  We’re talking travel and entertainment. No matter what path you take in the ever-growing Hospitality world, food and beverage is at the core.  And no college knows the business of F&B like the CIA.
A CIA degree spells success—our 50,000  alumni are proof of that!
They’re not only accomplished chefs; they’re influential leaders in the food world.
Global Head & VP of Luxury and Lifestyle Food and Beverage
“The first time I visited, I knew I had finally found a school that teaches the traditions of the world’s cuisines...It’s the best culinary school in the world.”
CIA faculty members have unmatched credentials.
Learn directly from the people who wrote the book on food!
Get valuable hands-on instruction from acclaimed master chefs, successful restaurateurs, wine experts, forward-thinking nutritionists, and many other food authorities.
Gain well-rounded, food-focused knowledge from accomplished historians, anthropologists, marketing and management experts, authors, and more.
Be part of a vibrant campus and close-knit community,
where everyone speaks your language—food. And your dorm has a full-sized kitchen!
Student clubs and activities, athletics and fitness, entertainment and fun...you’ll find it all at the New York campus.
At our California campus, you’ll have fun exploring Napa Valley’s bountiful farms, vineyards, culture, and outdoor activities.
Enjoy the energy and action of our Texas campus, set among the shops, restaurants, and attractions of San Antonio.
Meet our students, read about what they're working on in class,
and follow their travel adventures.  Our Blog has it all!

We’re shaping the future of the food industry and driving change for a better world. You will too!
The CIA and top universities and scientists together, nurturing a healthier, more sustainable, and delicious future.
Our thought leadership conferences guide the food industry toward the next wave of global change.
Our experts help foodservice operators translate science into innovative, practical strategies that drive their businesses.
The CIA is a food lover’s paradise—a hub for tasting, learning, experiencing, and celebrating life.
Dine at our family of 10 student-staffed restaurants and meet the food leaders of the future.
The ultimate CIA foodie adventure—dining, classes, demos, entertainment, and food innovation in downtown Napa, CA.
Hands-on and multi-day classes, where you can release your inner chef.
Your event will be both inventive and unique when you tap into our 75 years of food and hospitality experience.
Open House for Adult & Transfer Students - NY
Exciting things are happening at CIA campuses and beyond thanks to our dedicated faculty, students, staff, and alumni.
Check out these CIA headlines and more.
Joseph Phelps Vineyards President Delivers CIA Commencement Address
Clarice Turner, a globally recognized senior management executive and president of Joseph Phelps Vineyards, spoke to graduates at the CIA’s Greystone campus in St. Helena, CA on December 19.
Chef-Restaurateur Drew Curren Addresses Graduates of His Alma Mater
Drew Curren, chef and co-founder of the Austin-based ELM Restaurant Group, delivered the commencement address at the Texas campus of The Culinary Institute of America in San Antonio on December 19.
Google Exec Speaks to CIA Baccalaureate Graduates
Michiel Bakker, director of global programs for real estate and workplace services at Google, addressed bachelor’s degree recipients at The Culinary Institute of America on December 19.
Marriott Food & Beverage Exec Returns to Alma Mater as Commencement Speaker
Brad Nelson, vice president of global food and beverage for Marriott International, delivered the commencement keynote to associate degree graduates at the New York campus of the CIA on December 19.

CIA Students, Faculty, and Alumni Bios

Securing financial aid to help pay for your CIA education is easy. Our goal is to set you on your food career path as soon as possible! Our team is here to guide you through the financial planning process and answer any questions you may have. Here’s where you start:
Step 1: Apply for admission to the CIA.
All United States citizens should file a Free Application for Federal Student Aid (or “
,” a word you’ll get to know well) at

or by using the myStudentAid app. The CIA’s federal code is 007304. When you have received a Student Aid Report (SAR) from the federal processing center, you’ll know that your application has been processed and the review procedure can begin.
The CIA may request additional documentation, such as copies of your (or your parents’) IRS federal tax transcripts.
File your FAFSA at least five to six months prior to the CIA enrollment season for which you are applying. If desired, you can contact
CIA Student Financial and Registration Services
to be sure of filing the appropriate forms for your entry date.
helpful tips to avoid common errors when completing the FAFSA

Upon completion of the financial aid forms and receipt of the requested documentation, the CIA will evaluate your existing aid package to ensure all federal and institutional funds listed are accurate and available to you. If you have any questions along the way, we’ll help you find the answers. Call 845-451-1500 or e-mail
Step 3: Check out which other financial aid programs are available.

In addition to what’s in your financial aid package, you should explore other forms of aid to reduce costs further. We’ll point you in the right direction to locate external funding opportunities, such as
to learn about the costs for your program. Also use our
to better  understand what you’ll be paying.
Aid Suspension Due to Drug Conviction

The Higher Education Act of 1965 suspends financial aid eligibility for students who have been convicted under federal or state law for the sale or possession of drugs, if the offense occurred during a period of enrollment for which the student was receiving federal student aid.
If you have a conviction for this offense, call the Federal Student Aid Information Center at 1-800-433-3243 to find out how this law applies to you.

If you have lost your federal student aid eligibility because of a drug conviction, you can regain eligibility by successfully completing a qualified drug rehabilitation program or passing two unannounced drug tests administered by such a program.

You may also regain your eligibility if your conviction is reversed, set aside, or removed from your record so that fewer than two convictions for sale or three convictions for possession remain on your record.

Apply to The Culinary Institute of America
Applying to the CIA is easy through our online portal. The application is designed to help us get to know you and your areas of interest. Just follow these steps to get started:
and complete your application  or use the
Answer some short essay questions. You can do this in writing or via an in-person or phone interview.
Sign, date, and submit your application along with the $50 application fee.

Ask for a recommendation from a former teacher, employer, or professional colleague. Include that recommendation with your application or provide us with your recommender’s contact information so we can get a verbal recommendation.
Contact your high school or previous college and request that they send your official transcripts to the CIA Admissions Office.

to answer any additional questions you have.
How to Apply: Associate & Bachelor’s Degrees
Scheduling a visit to one of our world-class campuses is easy and convenient. Just choose your campus, and you will see our schedule of admissions tours and events.
Don’t let financial concerns stand in the way of your education. The CIA has a variety of scholarships that can help make your dreams a reality.
Visiting chef demos, major conferences, and special events on campus let you rub elbows with stars of the food world.
